Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Building a Shareable Knowledge Base for Teaching College Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This conference aims to contribute to increased quality of college mathematics teaching and learning. It will do so by addressing how to generate, store, and share knowledge about effective college mathematics teaching. Participants will discuss the practical and theoretical issues about building a knowledge based for teaching college mathematics. During the conference, approximately 20 participants will begin to develop a formal system for generating, storing, and sharing knowledge of college mathematics instruction. Before the conference, the participants chosen will begin drafting written instructional products and use them at the conference to share instructional knowledge.

A main goal of the conference is to elaborate a framework for potential authors of written instructional products to describe what knowledge they should capture and what type of scholarly work can be done to generate such knowledge. The conference includes a draft framework, called “Scholarly Design,” which is based on research and scholarship of teaching and learning. The major goal of the conference is to produce a framework characterizing Design Scholarship in mathematics, illustrated with specific examples of such scholarship. It is anticipated that this framework will help faculty begin to engage in building a knowledge base for teaching in more effective ways. Two additional benefits are expected to emerge from supporting this community of college mathematics teachers as they engage in Design Scholarship to build a knowledge base for teaching. First, college mathematics teachers may consume the published products, adapt them for their students and instructional contexts, and implement high quality lessons. Second, teachers who engage in the process of Design Scholarship will learn about teaching (or how to analyze teaching) that may apply to other mathematics lessons, not just the lesson that is the focus of their work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the Summer of 2020, the PI and Co-PI held an NSF funded workshop/conference titled, Building a Knowledge Base for Teaching Undergraduate Mathematics. They invited 18 mathematicians and mathematics educators from around the US to participate in this workshop. Due to Covid-19 restrictions the workshops were held online over 3 weeks rather than in-person over a 3-days. The goals of the workshop were:  

(a) Understanding the current knowledge base of teaching in undergraduate mathematics; (b) Developing a written genre that can be used to store and share important knowledge of teaching that is not widely available; (c) Write up examples of this genre and use them to better understand what features are needed/useful to best share important knowledge of teaching; d) Create a book that explains the work done at the conference and offers multiple high-quality examples of this written genre.

The workshop included four, two-hour sessions with all members present, and 3 session in small groups to discuss the details of a participants draft in this new genre (what we came to call a Lesson Analysis Manuscript, or LAM). The sessions were very productive. The first two were largely about building a consensus about what kind of knowledge is needed and how this genre relates to other available instructional materials (such as inquiry-oriented curriculum materials). The small group sessions were instrumental in testing out and discussion specific attempts and sharing individual visions of what the genre could contain and be. The latter sessions were helpful in refining/framing the content of the LAMs and to solidify a structure for the write-ups.

After the workshop sessions, we worked asynchronously in small groups to write a “how to” chapter to serve as a guide for us, as well as others, on how to write LAMs. We then used the ideas from that chapter to refine our individual chapters (19 of the 20 participants were invited to write a LAM, with the current MAA president the one participant who we did not expect to write up a LAM due to his heavy load as president). After completion of the “how to” chapter, participants revised their chapters/LAMs to meet the expectations in the chapters. Drafts were due by the first of September, 2020. The PI and Co-PI read through each one and offered feedback. 12 of the chapters were selected for publication in the book (with some participants not able to submit a full, revised draft due time constraints, particularly increased time constraints due to preparing for online/blended instruction due to the Covid-19 restrictions).

Currently, the PI and Co-PI are making final edits on the manuscript of the book from the conference. MAA has agreed, in principle, to publish the book and we will be sending a complete manuscript to them in a few short weeks for them to review.

Surveys of the conference participants showed that they thought the problem that the conference addressed was important and the work we started is promising. Many of the participants have committed to be actively engaged in future efforts to share the work and build on what was started in this conference. Four journals have agreed that the LAM genre is a good fit and will accept LAMs submitted for publication.

The PI and Co-PI are planning on writing another NSF grant to hold another conference that will take up the issue of how to do the work of Lesson Analysis which we introduce in the book. The current book focuses on the written genre, but does not adequately help readers know how to do the work of studying teaching, and learning from practice, that would result in a LAM.   

Instructional knowledge is being developed by individuals, or in groups in a particular local context, but the community of college mathematics instructors does not have a field of scholarship that allows this knowledge to be vetted, shared, and stored; nor does the community have a clear idea of how to support others to learn from their own teaching practice in a way that can contribute to a broader knowledge base. We feel like we have made significant strides in this area and will continue to work on developing ideas about, and resources for, sharing instructional knowledge in college mathematics teaching.
